Description: Louisiana Generating, an electric generating company owned by NRG Energy Inc., agreed to a settlement at its Big Cajun II coal-fired power plant in New Roads, La., which will result in the elimination of over 27,300 tons of harmful emissions per year. The settlement, lodged in federal court in Baton Rouge, will require Louisiana Generating to spend approximately $250 million to reduce air pollution and also requires the company to pay a civil fine of $3.5 million and spend $10.5 million on environmental mitigation projects.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the issuance of an administrative order instituting and simultaneously settling charges under the Commodity Exchange Act of attempted manipulation and false reporting against respondent Mirant Americas Energy Marketing LP, a wholly owned, indirect subsidiary of Mirant Corporation, based in Atlanta, Georgia, and assessing a civil penalty of $12.5 million.

Mirant Energy Trading LLC entered into an agreement with the U.S. government resolving an ongoing federal investigation into the submission of knowingly inaccurate reports by former traders of former subsidiary Mirant Americas Energy Marketing, LP concerning the commodities market for natural gas.

In a Clean Air Act settlement, Mirant Mid-Atlantic agreed to eliminate nearly 29,000 tons of harmful pollution each year generated by its four electricity generating plants in Maryland and Virginia. It also agreed to pay a pay a $500,000 civil penalty, to be divided between Virginia and the United States, and spend at least $1 million on nine projects designed to reduce particulate matter and fugitive dust emissions from the Potomac River plant.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: GenOn Power Generation agreed to pay $1 million to Connecticut and New Jersey as part of the settlement of a lawsuit concerning emissions from a power plant in Pennsylvania.
Info Source: Connecticut, New Jersey Settle Clean Air Lawsuit with Owners of Coal-burning Generating Plant, States News Service, May 15, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: The California Attorney General announced a $749.7 million proposed settlement with Mirant Corporation to resolve allegations of price gouging and other unlawful conduct during the California Energy Crisis of 2000-01.
Maryland entered into a Consent Decree with NRG Chalk Point LLC and related entities covering nitrogen exceedances at the Chalk Point and Dickerson electric generating stations.

The California Attorney General announced a $460 million settlement with Reliant Energy, Inc. to resolve claims the company gouged ratepayers, withheld power and manipulated electricity and natural gas prices during the California Energy Crisis of 2000-01. The AGs of Washington and Oregon also participated in the case.
Mirant agreed to pay $1.1 million in settlement of environmental allegations concerning its Potrero Power Plant.
GenOn agreed to pay $2.5 million in settlement of allegations one of its powerplants illegally discharged oil and other pollutants directly into the Potomac River.

Agency: Connecticut Department of Energy & Environmental Protection

On April 17, 2006, during the hour ending 16:OO and 17:00, Reliant Supply had an obligation to deploy 204 megawatts (MW) fiom LaaRs, but failed to deploy 139 MW of this amount from its Location within 10 minutes of ERCOT's deployment instruction
Violations of consumer protection rules concerning late customer payments.
Failure to timely issue bills and failure to obtain customer agreement prior to providing bills electronically in lieu of written bills delivered via U.S. mail
Failure to maintain and produce authorization of verification and its failure to provide retail electric service on the agreed approximate service start dates, resulting in a loss of service

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved settlement agreements between the PUC's independent Bureau of Investigation & Enforcement and three electric generation suppliers--Green Mountain Energy Company, Greenlight Energy Inc. and Discount Power Inc.  The settlements center on, but are not limited to, alleged misleading and deceptive telemarketing practices and unauthorized customer enrollments.
Investigation into the company's marketing and sales practices as a licensed electric generation supplier (EGS) in Pennsylvania.
